review.title: On the Computation of Paracoherent Answer Sets
review.abstract: Answer Set Programming (ASP) is a well-established formalism for nonmonotonic reasoning. An ASP program can have no answer set due to cyclic default negation. In this case, it is not possible to draw any conclusion, even if this is not intended. Recently, several paracoherent semantics have been proposed that address this issue, and several potential applications for these semantics have been identified. However, paracoherent semantics have essentially been inapplicable in practice, due to the lack of efficient algorithms and implementations. In this paper, this lack is addressed, and several different algorithms to compute semi-stable and semi-equilibrium models are proposed and implemented into an answer set solving framework. An empirical performance comparison among the new algorithms on benchmarks from ASP competitions is given as well.

metadata.title: On the Computation of Paracoherent Answer Sets

sections.text: ar Xiv: 170 7.06 813v 1 [cs.L O] 21 JuAnswer Set Programming (ASP) is an established formalism for non-monotonous thinking. An ASP program cannot have an answer due to cyclical default negation. In this case, it is not possible to draw conclusions, even if this is not intended. Recently, several paracoherent semantics have been proposed to address this problem, and several potential applications for this semantics have been identified. In practice, however, paracoherent semantics has essentially not been applicable due to the lack of efficient algorithms and implementations. This paper addresses this deficiency, and several different algorithms for calculating semi-stable and semi-equilibrium models are proposed and translated into a solution framework for responses. An empirical performance comparison between the new algorithms to benchmarks from ASP competitions is also given.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Many advances in artificial intelligence research have been made in recent decades.

sections.heading: 2 Preliminaries
sections.text: We begin by remembering the semantics of the response sentences and then present the paracoherent semantics of semi-stable and semi-equilibrium models.

sections.heading: 2.1 Answer Set Programming
sections.text: A disjunctive rule r is of the forma1 (· · · al ← b1,..., bm, not bm ² 1,..., not bn, (1) where all ai and b j are atoms (of Σ) and l ≥ 0, n ≥ m ≥ 0 and l + n > 0; does not represent negation-as-failure. The set H (r) = {a1, al} is the head of r, while B + (r) = {b1,..., bm} and B − (r) tics = {bm + 1,., bn} are the positive body and the negative body of r, respectively the body of r is the answer of B + (r).B − (r). We denote At (r) = H (r).B (r), the set of all atoms occurring in r.

sections.heading: 2.2 Paracoherent ASP
sections.text: This semantics fulfills three desiderata properties defined by [4].Semi-StableModels. Inoue and Sakama ([34]) have introduced semi-stable model semantics ([34]).We consider an extended signature to be stable model semantics ([34]).Ka can be intuitively interpreted as a believed model. Semantically, we resort to subsets of interpretations that we consider to be interpretations and truth values.

sections.heading: 3 Computation of a Paracoherent Answer Set
4 Implementation and Experiments
sections.text: In fact, it is not the case that one imagines it in a way that one imagines it, in a way that one imagines it, in a way that one imagines it in a different way: in a different way, in a different way, in a different way, in a different way, in a different way, in a different way, in a different way, in a different way, in a different way, in a different way, in a different way, in a different way, in a different way.

sections.heading: 5 Related Work
sections.text: In fact, it is the case that most people who are able are able to determine for themselves what they want and what they do not want.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we have addressed the problem of calculating paracoherent response sets, namely semi-stable and stable equilibrium models that have not been addressed so far. We have proposed a series of algorithms based on program transformation followed by calls to a response solver. We have conducted an experimental analysis of these algorithms using incoherent ASP competition programs, with analysis of incoherent response set programs being the primary application we envisage for paracoherent response sets. Experiments show that minimizing and columns exceed other tested algorithms, and the results show that calculating a paracoherent response set is not only a theoretical problem, but also a difficult one in practice.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: This work was partially supported by the EU funding agreement H2020 Marie Skłodowska-Curie No. 690974 "MIREL," MIUR within the project "SI-LAB BA2KNOW," by MISE within the project "PIUCultura," N. F / 020016 / 01-02 / X27, and by GNCS-INDAM.

referenceMentions.context: Answer Set Programming (ASP) is a premier formalism for nonmonotonic reasoning (see, [8, 19]).
Answer Set Programming (ASP) is a premier formalism for nonmonotonic reasoning (see, [8, 19]).

ASP is based on the stable model (or answer set) semantics introduced by [21] and is used to solve complex problems in Artificial Intelligence [17], Bioinformatics [12], Databases [27]; Game Theory [5]; more recently ASP has been applied to solve industrial applications [14, 22, 13].

To distinguish this situation from reasoning under classical logical contradiction due to strong negation, called paraconsistent reasoning, it has been referred to it as paracoherent reasoning [4].

In order to deal with this, [34] introduced the semi-stable model semantics that coincides with answer set semantics whenever a program has some answer set, but admits paracoherent models for each classically consistent program.
Recently, [4] have improved this kind of semantics avoiding some anomalies with respect to basic modal logic properties, resorting to the equilibrium logic [31].

Different possible applications of these paracoherent semantics have been identified, such as debugging, model building, inconsistency-tolerant query answering, diagnosis, planning and reasoning about actions; and computational complexity aspects have been studied [4].
Finally, we report the results of an experimental activity conducted on benchmarks from ASP competitions [11], identifying the more efficient algorithm.

The complexity of various reasoning tasks with paracoherent answer sets has been analyzed in [4]: while determining the existence of paracoherent answer sets is NP-complete (it is sufficient to test for existence of classical models), paracoherent answer set checking is ΠP2 -complete, leading to Σ P 3 -completeness for brave, and Π3 -completeness for cautious reasoning.
In fact, by properties of semi-stable and semi-equilibrium models, this kind of programs admit always a paracoherent answer set [4].

However, [4] have shown that only semi-stable semantics [34] and semi-equilibrium semantics [4] satisfy the following desiderata properties: (i) every consistent answer set of a program corresponds to a paracoherent answer set (answer set coverage); (ii) if a program has some (consistent) answer set, then its paracoherent answer sets correspond to answer sets (congruence); (iii) if a program has a classical model, then it has a paracoherent answer set (classical coherence); (iv) a minimal set of atoms should be undefined (minimal undefinedness); (v) every true atom must be derived from the program (justifiability).

[29] proposed a tableaux-based method where candidate models are generated and then tested for minimality.
[23] proposed a method able to reduce minimality tests on candidate models.
The usage of hyperresolution for minimal models of first-order clauses was presented in [9] and implemented in Prolog.
As observed in [26] these approaches do not take profit of modern non-chronological-backtracking-based solving technology.
This limit was overcome in [26] by an algorithm for computing minimal models of SAT formulas that is based on the same principle as the Minimize algorithm.
The computation of minimal models of SAT formulae can be reduced to computing a Minimal Set over a Monotone Predicate (MSMP) [25].
Thus algorithms for MSMP such as those described in [28] could be adapted (by properly taking into account the jump in computational complexity) for computing paracoherent answer sets.

metadata.abstractText: Answer Set Programming (ASP) is a well-established formalism for nonmonotonic reasoning. An ASP program can have no answer set due to cyclic default negation. In this case, it is not possible to draw any conclusion, even if this is not intended. Recently, several paracoherent semantics have been proposed that address this issue, and several potential applications for these semantics have been identified. However, paracoherent semantics have essentially been inapplicable in practice, due to the lack of efficient algorithms and implementations. In this paper, this lack is addressed, and several different algorithms to compute semi-stable and semi-equilibrium models are proposed and implemented into an answer set solving framework. An empirical performance comparison among the new algorithms on benchmarks from ASP competitions is given as well.
